article.title: The signaling lipid sphingosine 1-phosphate regulates mechanical pain

article.abstract: Somatosensory neurons mediate responses to diverse mechanical stimuli, from innocuous touch to noxious pain. While recent studies have identified distinct populations of A mechanonociceptors (AMs) that are required for mechanical pain, the molecular underpinnings of mechanonociception remain unknown.

sections.introduction: Pain is a complex sensation. It serves to protect organisms from harmful stimuli, but can also become chronic and debilitating following tissue injury and disease.
sections.methods: S1pr3mcherry/+ and S1pr3-/- mice were obtained from Jackson Laboratory and backcrossed to C57bl6/J.
sections.results: We first examined a variety of somatosensory behaviors in mice lacking S1PR3 (Kono et al., 2004) (S1pr3tm1Rlp/Mmnc; referred to herein as S1PR3 KO).
sections.discussion: We now show that S1P signaling via S1PR3 is a key pathway that tunes mechanical pain sensitivity.

article.insights_summary: We show that sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) is required for mechanical pain sensation and that S1P signaling via S1PR3 is a key pathway that tunes mechanical pain sensitivity.
